# Headers

Headers are used to create a document's structure and outline. Markdown supports six levels of headers, from the most important (`H1`) to the least (`H6`).

# H1 Header - Main Title
## H2 Header - Section Title
### H3 Header - Subsection Title
#### H4 Header - Sub-subsection Title
##### H5 Header - Minor Section
###### H6 Header - Smallest Header

text-formatting/emphasis.md:
# Emphasis

Emphasis is used to highlight text, typically by making it bold or italic.

**Bold text** using double asterisks or __double underscores__

*Italic text* using single asterisks or _single underscores_

***Bold and italic*** using triple asterisks or ___triple underscores___

# Other Text Formats

Beyond emphasis, Markdown supports other useful text formats.

~~Strikethrough text~~ using double tildes

`Inline code` using backticks

You can also use subscript<sub>text</sub> and superscript<sup>text</sup> with HTML tags.

# Lists

Markdown supports several types of lists for organizing content. Each type has its own dedicated file for detailed examples.

### List Types

- [Unordered Lists](./lists/unordered-lists.md)
- [Ordered Lists](./lists/ordered-lists.md)
- [Task Lists](./lists/task-lists.md)

### Mixed Lists

You can mix different list types together.

1. First item
   - Nested unordered item
2. Second item
   1. Nested ordered item

# Unordered Lists

Unordered lists are used for items where the order does not matter. You can create them using hyphens, asterisks, or plus signs.

- First item
- Second item
  - Nested item
* Third item (using asterisk)
+ Fourth item (using plus sign)

---

# Ordered Lists

Ordered lists are used for items where the sequence is important.

1. First ordered item
2. Second ordered item
   1. Nested ordered item
3. Third ordered item

---

lists/task-lists.md:
# Task Lists (Checkboxes)

Task lists are a special type of list where each item has a checkbox.

- [x] Completed task
- [ ] Incomplete task
  - [x] Nested completed task
- [ ] Another incomplete task

# Links and Images

Markdown makes it simple to embed links and images in your documents.

### Links

[Inline link](https://example.com)

[Link with title](https://example.com "This is a title")

[Reference link][1]

Direct URL: https://example.com

[1]: https://example.com

### Images

![Alt text](https://via.placeholder.com/300x200 "Image title")

![Reference-style image][image-ref]

[image-ref]: https://via.placeholder.com/400x300 "Reference image"

# Footnotes

Footnotes allow you to add notes and references without cluttering the body of the document.

Here's a sentence with a footnote[^1].

And here is another one[^longnote].

[^1]: This is the first footnote.
[^longnote]: This is a longer footnote that can span multiple lines.

advanced-features/admonitions.md:
# Admonitions / Callouts

Admonitions, or callouts, are an extension of blockquotes used to highlight critical information. Support may vary across Markdown renderers.

> [!NOTE]
> This is a note callout. Useful for tips or non-essential information.

> [!IMPORTANT]
> This is an important callout. It highlights key information.

> [!WARNING]
> This is a warning callout. Use it for critical or dangerous points.

# Escaping Characters

To display a literal character that has special meaning in Markdown syntax, use a backslash `\` in front of it.

\*This is not italic\*

\# This is not a header
